title: Knowledge Accumulation and Diffusion: Analysing Heterogeneity in an Interconnected World
abstractText:
Innovation is an important driver of long-run economic growth, with innovations such as the PC or the Toyota manufacturing system offering clear evidence for a close link between innovation effort (investment in research and development , R&D) and successful development.

A renewed interest among policymakers in the patterns of ‘knowledge accumulation’ (through R&D) and spillovers (the Newtonian idea of ‘standing on the shoulders of giants’), and the means to benefit from domestic and international knowledge investments for economies at different stages of development is the prime motivation for this research.

In developed economies industrial policy claims certain sectors are ‘more important’ than others and provides them with generous support; in the developing world experts express concerns over a reduction in spillovers from agricultural knowledge investments in the rich countries and a limited domestic base for agricultural productivity increase.

The project will use novel panel econometric methods to revisit knowledge production and diffusion at the sector level (agriculture, manufacturing, services), allowing for a number of innovations in the flexible modelling of production and the distinction between knowledge spillovers and global economic shocks which may distort the existing spillover analysis.
